notes:
1. Concept

The Temperature-Entropy (T-s) diagram is a fundamental tool in thermodynamics for visualizing and analyzing energy transfer during processes and cycles. The vertical axis represents Absolute Temperature ($T$) and the horizontal axis represents Specific Entropy ($s$).

2. Key Feature: Heat Transfer

The most significant feature of a T-s diagram is that for any internally reversible process, the area under the process curve represents the heat transferred per unit mass.

$$ q_{rev} = \int_{1}^{2} T ds $$
  • If the process moves to the right (increasing $s$), heat is added to the system ($q > 0$).
  • If the process moves to the left (decreasing $s$), heat is rejected from the system ($q < 0$).

For a reversible cycle, the area enclosed by the cycle path represents the net heat transfer, which is also equal to the net work done ($q_{net} = w_{net}$).

3. Common Processes on T-s Diagram

  • Isentropic Process ($\Delta s = 0$): A reversible adiabatic process appears as a vertical line.
  • Isothermal Process ($\Delta T = 0$): A constant temperature process appears as a horizontal line.

The T-s diagram also typically includes the saturation dome (liquid-vapor region). The peak of the dome is the critical point. To the left is the saturated liquid line, and to the right is the saturated vapor line.

solvedExamples.question: On a T-s diagram, what does the area under the curve of a reversible process represent?
solvedExamples.explanation: For a reversible process, $dQ = T ds$. Therefore, the integral $\int T ds$, which corresponds to the area under the curve on a T-s plot, represents the total heat transfer $Q$.

solvedExamples.question: An isentropic expansion of steam in a turbine would appear as what kind of line on a T-s diagram?
solvedExamples.explanation: Isentropic means constant entropy ($s_1 = s_2$). On a T-s diagram, this is a vertical line. Since it is an expansion, the temperature and pressure typically drop, so the line goes downwards.
